ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned all about ethics, law, and philosophy pertaining to being a naval officer.  We did a lot of case studies too to aid in our learning.
I learned about fundamentals in Enlightenment-era philosophy, schools of thoughts and their applications to military-focused decision-making and leadership.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: the discussions, I enjoyed talking with my classmates and the instructor on difficult cases.  I felt it was a safe space to share opinions, even if mine were contrary to someone else's.
Weaknesses: felt like too much reading at times.  Sometimes, the journal entries felt more like a chore rather than a reflection.  It would help if these were not every week.  Spent way too much time on ancient philosophers for my liking.  We also never got to roleplay the NJP.

Strengths: Compelling readings/case studies. Reflection portions of homework entries were conducive to classroom learning. Peer-to-peer discussions were always insightful and exciting. instructor was excellent.
Weaknesses: Due to high amount of coverage, some schools of thoughts were covered superficially.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this to other ROTC midshipmen (and it's required for them).  It could be interesting in the future as I've heard they are now giving out Yale College graduation credit for this course.  If that is the case, then the course should be broadened so other students will find it interesting.  The time slot is not very fun though (7:00am), so be warned.
